Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1972, Thomas Sankara 
was swept into a revolution for a country not his own. Hailing from the West African nation 
of Burkina Faso— then known as Upper Volta— the 22-year-old soldier 
had travelled to Madagascar to study at their military academy. But upon arriving, 
he found a nation in conflict. Local revolutionaries 
sought to wrest control of Madagascar from France’s lingering colonial rule. These protestors 
inspired Sankara to read works by socialist leaders
like Karl Marx and seek wisdom from military strategy. When he returned to Upper Volta in 1973, Sankara was determined to free 
his country from its colonial legacy. Born in 1949, Sankara was raised 
in a relatively privileged household as the third of ten children. His parents wanted him to be a priest, 
but like many of his peers, Sankara saw the military 
as the perfect institution to rid Upper Volta of corruption. After returning from Madagascar, he became famous for his charisma 
and transparent oratorial style— but he was less popular 
with the reigning government. Led by President Jean-Baptiste Ouédraogo, this administration came to power 
in the 3rd consecutive coup d’état in Upper Volta’s recent history. The administration’s policies 
were a far cry from the sweeping changes 
Sankara proposed, but, by 1981, 
Sankara’s popularity won out, earning him a role 
in Ouédraogo’s government. Nicknamed “Africa’s Che Guevara," 
Sankara rapidly rose through the ranks, and within two years, 
he was appointed Prime Minister. In his new role, 
he delivered rallying speeches to impoverished communities, 
women, and young people. He even tried to persuade 
other governments to form alliances based on their shared colonial legacy. But Ouédraogo and his advisors 
felt threatened by Sankara’s new position. They thought his communist beliefs would 
harm alliances with capitalist countries, and just months 
after becoming Prime Minister, Ouédraogo’s administration 
forced Sankara from the job and placed him on house arrest. Little did the President know this act would fuel Upper Volta’s 
4th coup d’état in 17 years. Civilian protests 
ensued around the capital, and the government ground to a halt while Sankara tried to negotiate 
a peaceful transition. During this time, Blaise Compaoré, Sankara’s friend 
and fellow former soldier, foiled another coup that included 
an attempt on Sankara’s life. Eventually, Ouédraogo resigned 
without further violence, and on August 4, 1983, Thomas Sankara 
became the new President of Upper Volta. Finally in charge, 
Sankara launched an ambitious program for social and economic change. As one of his first agenda items, 
he renamed the country from its French colonial title 
"Upper Volta" to "Burkina Faso," which translates 
to “Land of Upright Men." Over the next four years he established 
a nation-wide literacy campaign, ordered the planting 
of over 10 million trees, and composed a new national anthem— all while cutting down 
inflated government employee salaries. But perhaps the most unique element 
of Sankara’s revolution was his dedication to gender equality. He cultivated a movement 
for women’s liberation, outlawing forced marriages, 
polygamy and genital mutilation. He was the first African leader to appoint
women to key political positions and actively recruit them to the military. However, Sankara’s socialist policies 
were met with much resistance. Many students and elites 
believed his economic plans would alienate Burkina Faso 
from its capitalist peers. His crackdown 
on the misuse of public funds turned government officials 
against him as well. After four years, 
what began as an empowering revolution had isolated many influential Burkinabes. But Sankara was not ready 
to yield his power. He executed 
increasingly authoritarian actions, including banning trade unions 
and the free press. Eventually, his autocratic tendencies turned even his closest friends 
against him. On October 15, 1987, Sankara was conducting a meeting 
when a group of assailants swarmed his headquarters. Sankara was assassinated in the attack, and many believe the raid was ordered 
by his friend Blaise Compaoré. Though his legacy is complicated, many of Sankara’s policies have proven 
themselves to be ahead of their time. In the past decade, Burkinabe youth have celebrated 
Sankara’s political philosophy, and nearby countries like Ghana have even 
adopted Sankara’s economic models. On March 2, 2019 a statue of Sankara 
was erected in Burkina Faso’s capital, establishing his place 
as an icon of revolution for his country and throughout the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the most unique element of Sankara’s revolution?
Options: A. Women’s Liberation Movement, B. New national anthem, C. Lower government employee salaries, D. Nation-wide literacy campaign
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
In 1972, Thomas Sankara 
was swept into a revolution for a country not his own. Hailing from the West African nation 
of Burkina Faso— then known as Upper Volta— the 22-year-old soldier 
had travelled to Madagascar to study at their military academy. But upon arriving, 
he found a nation in conflict. Local revolutionaries 
sought to wrest control of Madagascar from France’s lingering colonial rule. These protestors 
inspired Sankara to read works by socialist leaders
like Karl Marx and seek wisdom from military strategy. When he returned to Upper Volta in 1973, Sankara was determined to free 
his country from its colonial legacy. Born in 1949, Sankara was raised 
in a relatively privileged household as the third of ten children. His parents wanted him to be a priest, 
but like many of his peers, Sankara saw the military 
as the perfect institution to rid Upper Volta of corruption. After returning from Madagascar, he became famous for his charisma 
and transparent oratorial style— but he was less popular 
with the reigning government. Led by President Jean-Baptiste Ouédraogo, this administration came to power 
in the 3rd consecutive coup d’état in Upper Volta’s recent history. The administration’s policies 
were a far cry from the sweeping changes 
Sankara proposed, but, by 1981, 
Sankara’s popularity won out, earning him a role 
in Ouédraogo’s government. Nicknamed “Africa’s Che Guevara," 
Sankara rapidly rose through the ranks, and within two years, 
he was appointed Prime Minister. In his new role, 
he delivered rallying speeches to impoverished communities, 
women, and young people. He even tried to persuade 
other governments to form alliances based on their shared colonial legacy. But Ouédraogo and his advisors 
felt threatened by Sankara’s new position. They thought his communist beliefs would 
harm alliances with capitalist countries, and just months 
after becoming Prime Minister, Ouédraogo’s administration 
forced Sankara from the job and placed him on house arrest. Little did the President know this act would fuel Upper Volta’s 
4th coup d’état in 17 years. Civilian protests 
ensued around the capital, and the government ground to a halt while Sankara tried to negotiate 
a peaceful transition. During this time, Blaise Compaoré, Sankara’s friend 
and fellow former soldier, foiled another coup that included 
an attempt on Sankara’s life. Eventually, Ouédraogo resigned 
without further violence, and on August 4, 1983, Thomas Sankara 
became the new President of Upper Volta. Finally in charge, 
Sankara launched an ambitious program for social and economic change. As one of his first agenda items,

were met with much resistance. Many students and elites

on the misuse of public funds turned government officials 
against him as well. After four years,

to yield his power. He executed 
increasingly authoritarian actions, including banning trade unions 
and the free press. Eventually, his autocratic tendencies turned even his closest friends 
against him. On October 15, 1987, Sankara was conducting a meeting 
when a group of assailants swarmed his headquarters. Sankara was assassinated in the attack, and many believe the raid was ordered 
by his friend Blaise Compaoré. Though his legacy is complicated, many of Sankara’s policies have proven 
themselves to be ahead of their time. In the past decade, Burkinabe youth have celebrated 
Sankara’s political philosophy, and nearby countries like Ghana have even 
adopted Sankara’s economic models. On March 2, 2019 a statue of Sankara 
was erected in Burkina Faso’s capital, establishing his place 
as an icon of revolution for his country and throughout the world.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the April sun rises 
on a pile of firewood, something royal stirs inside. This wasp queen is one of thousands 
who mated in late autumn and hibernated through the winter. Now she emerges into the spring air 
to begin her reign. Most of her sisters weren’t so lucky. While hibernating in compost piles 
and underground burrows, many sleeping queens 
were eaten by spiders. Warm winters caused by climate change 
led other queens to emerge early, only to find there was no available food. And some queens that survived the winter 
fell victim to the threats of spring, such as carnivorous plants, birds, 
and manmade pesticides. Our queen is the lone survivor 
of her old hive, and now, she must become 
the foundress of a new one. But first, breakfast. The queen heads for a citrus grove 
full of honeybee hives. The bees can be dangerous if provoked, but right now they’re paralyzed 
by the morning cold. Their hairy bodies are dripping 
with sugar water from an earlier feeding, and the resourceful queen 
licks them for a morning snack. Newly energized, our queen searches 
for a safe nesting area. This tree hollow, safe from rain, wind, 
and predators, is ideal. She chews the surrounding wood 
and plant fibers to make a paper-like pulp. Then she builds around 50 brood cells 
that comprise the beginning of her nest. Using sperm stored from last fall, the queen lays a fertilized egg 
into each cell, producing as many as 12 in 20 minutes. Within a week, 
these will hatch into female larva. But until then, the queen must hunt down 
smaller insects to feed her brood, all while expanding the hive, laying eggs,
and defending against intruders. Fortunately, our queen is well prepared. Unlike bees, wasps can sting as many times
as they need to. With such a busy schedule, 
the queen barely has time to feed herself. Luckily, she doesn’t have to. When she feeds an insect to her grubs, they digest the bug into a sugary 
substance that sustains their mother. By the end of July, these first larva 
have matured into adult workers, ready to take on foraging, 
building, and defense. The queen can now lay eggs full-time, sustaining herself on her worker’s spoils 
and their unfertilized eggs. Although each worker only lives 
for roughly 3 weeks, the queen’s continuous egg-laying 
swells their ranks. In just one summer, 
the nest reaches the size of a basketball, supporting thousands of workers. Such a large population needs to eat, and the nearby garden 
provides a veritable buffet. As the swarm descends, 
alarmed humans try to swat them. They even fight back with pesticides 
that purposefully poison wasps, and inadvertently impact 
a wide-range of local wildlife. But the wasps are actually vital 
to this ecosystem. Sitting at the top 
of the local invertebrate food chain, these insects keep spiders, mites, 
and centipedes, in check. Wasps consume crop-eating insects, making them particularly helpful 
for farms and gardens. They even pollinate fruits and vegetables, and help winemakers 
by biting into their grapes and jump-starting fermentation. This feast continues until autumn, 
when the foundress changes course. She begins grooming some eggs 
into a new generation of queens, while also laying unfertilized eggs that will mature into reproductive males 
called drones. This new crop of queens and males 
requires more food. But with summer over, 
the usual sources run dry, and the foraging wasps 
start taking more aggressive risks. By September, 
the hive’s organization deteriorates. Hungry workers no longer clean the nest 
and various scavengers move in. Just when it seems 
the hive can no longer sustain itself, the fertile queens and their drones 
depart in a massive swarm. As the days grow colder, 
the workers starve, and our queen 
reaches the end of her lifespan. But above, a swarm of reproductive wasps 
has successfully mated. The males die off shortly after, but the newly fertilized queens are ready 
to find shelter for their long sleep. And this woodpile looks like 
the perfect place to spend the winter.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long do worker wasps live for?
Options: A. 20 minutes, B. 1 week, C. 3 weeks, D. 1 year
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the typical fate of most wasp queens during hibernation? Options: A. They emerge early due to warm winters and find abundant food., B. They are eaten by spiders, other predators, or succumb to environmental threats., C. They survive to establish new hives and thrive in the spring., D. They die from lack of food and harsh winter conditions. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why do wasp queens often visit honeybee hives in the morning? Options: A. To attack and take over the hive for resources., B. To feed on the bees themselves for protein., C. To lick sugar water from the bees' bodies for sustenance., D. To steal honey from the hive for energy. Correct Option: C
Question 3: If you were a gardener trying to attract beneficial wasps to your garden, what would be an ideal feature to include? Options: A. A beehive to provide a source of food and attract other pollinators., B. A tree hollow or other safe nesting area to provide shelter., C. A source of pesticides to control other pests and reduce competition., D. A compost pile to attract other beneficial insects and provide nutrients. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is unique about the way wasps can defend themselves compared to bees? Options: A. Wasps can only sting once and then die., B. Wasps can sting multiple times without harm., C. Wasps are generally non-aggressive and avoid confrontations., D. Wasps rely on their speed to evade predators and avoid stinging. Correct Option: B
Question 5: How do wasp larvae contribute to the sustenance of their mother, the queen? Options: A. By producing a sugary substance from digested insects to feed the queen., B. By laying eggs to increase the hive population and provide more workers., C. By foraging for food outside the hive and bringing back nutrients., D. By defending the hive against predators and protecting the queen. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the typical lifespan of a worker wasp? Options: A. Several months, allowing them to contribute to the hive's growth., B. Roughly 3 weeks, requiring the queen to constantly lay new eggs., C. A few days, making them a short-lived but essential part of the hive., D. A year or more, allowing them to become a dominant force in the ecosystem. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Analyze the role of wasps in the ecosystem. What would likely happen if wasp populations declined significantly? Options: A. Spider and mite populations would decrease, causing a ripple effect in the ecosystem., B. Crop-eating insect populations would decrease, benefiting farmers and gardeners., C. Spider and mite populations would increase, potentially harming crops and gardens., D. Pollination of fruits and vegetables would increase, benefiting plant diversity. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How do wasps contribute to the process of winemaking? Options: A. By pollinating grapevines and increasing fruit production., B. By controlling pests that damage grapes and reducing disease., C. By biting into grapes and jump-starting fermentation to produce wine., D. By providing a source of yeast for fermentation and influencing flavor. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Synthesize the information about the wasp queen's life cycle. What is the primary goal of the queen's activities in the summer? Options: A. To establish a new hive, lay eggs, and expand the colony., B. To forage for food, defend the hive, and maintain the status quo., C. To groom a new generation of queens and prepare for succession., D. To prepare the hive for winter, reduce activity, and conserve energy. Correct Option: A
Question 10: Evaluate the impact of human actions on wasp populations. What is a potential consequence of using pesticides to control wasp populations? Options: A. The wasp population will decline, but other wildlife will be unaffected and thrive., B. The wasp population will decline, and other wildlife will benefit from reduced competition., C. The wasp population will decline, and other wildlife will also be harmed due to the broad impact of pesticides., D. The wasp population will increase, and other wildlife will be unaffected by the pesticides. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 6: What is the typical lifespan of a worker wasp? Options: A. Several months, allowing them to contribute to the hive's growth., B. Roughly 3 weeks, requiring the queen to constantly lay new eggs., C. A few days, making them a short-lived but essential part of the hive., D. A year or more, allowing them to become a dominant force in the ecosystem. Correct Option: B**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the lifespan of worker wasps, and both have similar answer options, with the correct answer being approximately 3 weeks.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **6**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the April sun rises 
on a pile of firewood, something royal stirs inside. This wasp queen is one of thousands 
who mated in late autumn and hibernated through the winter. Now she emerges into the spring air 
to begin her reign. Most of her sisters weren’t so lucky. While hibernating in compost piles 
and underground burrows, many sleeping queens 
were eaten by spiders. Warm winters caused by climate change 
led other queens to emerge early, only to find there was no available food. And some queens that survived the winter 
fell victim to the threats of spring, such as carnivorous plants, birds, 
and manmade pesticides. Our queen is the lone survivor 
of her old hive, and now, she must become 
the foundress of a new one. But first, breakfast. The queen heads for a citrus grove 
full of honeybee hives. The bees can be dangerous if provoked, but right now they’re paralyzed 
by the morning cold. Their hairy bodies are dripping 
with sugar water from an earlier feeding, and the resourceful queen 
licks them for a morning snack. Newly energized, our queen searches 
for a safe nesting area. This tree hollow, safe from rain, wind, 
and predators, is ideal. She chews the surrounding wood 
and plant fibers to make a paper-like pulp. Then she builds around 50 brood cells 
that comprise the beginning of her nest. Using sperm stored from last fall, the queen lays a fertilized egg 
into each cell, producing as many as 12 in 20 minutes. Within a week, 
these will hatch into female larva. But until then, the queen must hunt down 
smaller insects to feed her brood, all while expanding the hive, laying eggs,
and defending against intruders. Fortunately, our queen is well prepared. Unlike bees, wasps can sting as many times
as they need to. With such a busy schedule, 
the queen barely has time to feed herself. Luckily, she doesn’t have to. When she feeds an insect to her grubs, they digest the bug into a sugary 
substance that sustains their mother. By the end of July, these first larva 
have matured into adult workers, ready to take on foraging, 
building, and defense. The queen can now lay eggs full-time, sustaining herself on her worker’s spoils 
and their unfertilized eggs. Although each worker only lives 
for roughly 3 weeks, the queen’s continuous egg-laying 
swells their ranks. In just one summer, 
the nest reaches the size of a basketball, supporting thousands of workers. Such a large population needs to eat, and the nearby garden 
provides a veritable buffet. As the swarm descends, 
alarmed humans try to swat them. They even fight back with pesticides 
that purposefully poison wasps, and inadvertently impact 
a wide-range of local wildlife. But the wasps are actually vital 
to this ecosystem. Sitting at the top 
of the local invertebrate food chain, these insects keep spiders, mites, 
and centipedes, in check. Wasps consume crop-eating insects, making them particularly helpful 
for farms and gardens. They even pollinate fruits and vegetables, and help winemakers 
by biting into their grapes and jump-starting fermentation. This feast continues until autumn, 
when the foundress changes course. She begins grooming some eggs 
into a new generation of queens, while also laying unfertilized eggs that will mature into reproductive males 
called drones. This new crop of queens and males 
requires more food. But with summer over, 
the usual sources run dry, and the foraging wasps 
start taking more aggressive risks. By September, 
the hive’s organization deteriorates. Hungry workers no longer clean the nest 
and various scavengers move in. Just when it seems 
the hive can no longer sustain itself, the fertile queens and their drones 
depart in a massive swarm. As the days grow colder, 
the workers starve, and our queen 
reaches the end of her lifespan. But above, a swarm of reproductive wasps 
has successfully mated. The males die off shortly after, but the newly fertilized queens are ready 
to find shelter for their long sleep. And this woodpile looks like 
the perfect place to spend the winter.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How are wasps vital to the ecosystem?
Options: A. They can sting victims multiple times, B. They keep spiders, mites and garden pests in check by eating them, C. Strongest muscles in the insect kingdom, D. Ability to hibernate over winter
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the typical fate of most wasp queens during hibernation? Options: A. They emerge early due to warm winters and find abundant food., B. They are eaten by spiders, other predators, or succumb to environmental threats., C. They survive to establish new hives and thrive in the spring., D. They die from lack of food and harsh winter conditions. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why do wasp queens often visit honeybee hives in the morning? Options: A. To attack and take over the hive for resources., B. To feed on the bees themselves for protein., C. To lick sugar water from the bees' bodies for sustenance., D. To steal honey from the hive for energy. Correct Option: C
Question 3: If you were a gardener trying to attract beneficial wasps to your garden, what would be an ideal feature to include? Options: A. A beehive to provide a source of food and attract other pollinators., B. A tree hollow or other safe nesting area to provide shelter., C. A source of pesticides to control other pests and reduce competition., D. A compost pile to attract other beneficial insects and provide nutrients. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is unique about the way wasps can defend themselves compared to bees? Options: A. Wasps can only sting once and then die., B. Wasps can sting multiple times without harm., C. Wasps are generally non-aggressive and avoid confrontations., D. Wasps rely on their speed to evade predators and avoid stinging. Correct Option: B
Question 5: How do wasp larvae contribute to the sustenance of their mother, the queen? Options: A. By producing a sugary substance from digested insects to feed the queen., B. By laying eggs to increase the hive population and provide more workers., C. By foraging for food outside the hive and bringing back nutrients., D. By defending the hive against predators and protecting the queen. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the typical lifespan of a worker wasp? Options: A. Several months, allowing them to contribute to the hive's growth., B. Roughly 3 weeks, requiring the queen to constantly lay new eggs., C. A few days, making them a short-lived but essential part of the hive., D. A year or more, allowing them to become a dominant force in the ecosystem. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Analyze the role of wasps in the ecosystem. What would likely happen if wasp populations declined significantly? Options: A. Spider and mite populations would decrease, causing a ripple effect in the ecosystem., B. Crop-eating insect populations would decrease, benefiting farmers and gardeners., C. Spider and mite populations would increase, potentially harming crops and gardens., D. Pollination of fruits and vegetables would increase, benefiting plant diversity. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How do wasps contribute to the process of winemaking? Options: A. By pollinating grapevines and increasing fruit production., B. By controlling pests that damage grapes and reducing disease., C. By biting into grapes and jump-starting fermentation to produce wine., D. By providing a source of yeast for fermentation and influencing flavor. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Synthesize the information about the wasp queen's life cycle. What is the primary goal of the queen's activities in the summer? Options: A. To establish a new hive, lay eggs, and expand the colony., B. To forage for food, defend the hive, and maintain the status quo., C. To groom a new generation of queens and prepare for succession., D. To prepare the hive for winter, reduce activity, and conserve energy. Correct Option: A
Question 10: Evaluate the impact of human actions on wasp populations. What is a potential consequence of using pesticides to control wasp populations? Options: A. The wasp population will decline, but other wildlife will be unaffected and thrive., B. The wasp population will decline, and other wildlife will benefit from reduced competition., C. The wasp population will decline, and other wildlife will also be harmed due to the broad impact of pesticides., D. The wasp population will increase, and other wildlife will be unaffected by the pesticides. Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Transcript**:
As the April sun rises 
on a pile of firewood, something royal stirs inside. This wasp queen is one of thousands 
who mated in late autumn and hibernated through the winter. Now she emerges into the spring air 
to begin her reign. Most of her sisters weren’t so lucky. While hibernating in compost piles 
and underground burrows, many sleeping queens 
were eaten by spiders. Warm winters caused by climate change 
led other queens to emerge early, only to find there was no available food. And some queens that survived the winter 
fell victim to the threats of spring, such as carnivorous plants, birds, 
and manmade pesticides. Our queen is the lone survivor 
of her old hive, and now, she must become 
the foundress of a new one. But first, breakfast. The queen heads for a citrus grove 
full of honeybee hives. The bees can be dangerous if provoked, but right now they’re paralyzed 
by the morning cold. Their hairy bodies are dripping 
with sugar water from an earlier feeding, and the resourceful queen 
licks them for a morning snack. Newly energized, our queen searches 
for a safe nesting area. This tree hollow, safe from rain, wind, 
and predators, is ideal. She chews the surrounding wood 
and plant fibers to make a paper-like pulp. Then she builds around 50 brood cells 
that comprise the beginning of her nest. Using sperm stored from last fall, the queen lays a fertilized egg 
into each cell, producing as many as 12 in 20 minutes. Within a week, 
these will hatch into female larva. But until then, the queen must hunt down 
smaller insects to feed her brood, all while expanding the hive, laying eggs,
and defending against intruders. Fortunately, our queen is well prepared. Unlike bees, wasps can sting as many times
as they need to. With such a busy schedule, 
the queen barely has time to feed herself. Luckily, she doesn’t have to. When she feeds an insect to her grubs, they digest the bug into a sugary 
substance that sustains their mother. By the end of July, these first larva 
have matured into adult workers, ready to take on foraging, 
building, and defense. The queen can now lay eggs full-time, sustaining herself on her worker’s spoils 
and their unfertilized eggs. Although each worker only lives 
for roughly 3 weeks, the queen’s continuous egg-laying 
swells their ranks. In just one summer, 
the nest reaches the size of a basketball, supporting thousands of workers. Such a large population needs to eat, and the nearby garden 
provides a veritable buffet. As the swarm descends, 
alarmed humans try to swat them. They even fight back with pesticides 
that purposefully poison wasps, and inadvertently impact 
a wide-range of local wildlife. But the wasps are actually vital 
to this ecosystem. Sitting at the top 
of the local invertebrate food chain, these insects keep spiders, mites, 
and centipedes, in check. Wasps consume crop-eating insects, making them particularly helpful 
for farms and gardens. They even pollinate fruits and vegetables, and help winemakers 
by biting into their grapes and jump-starting fermentation. This feast continues until autumn, 
when the foundress changes course. She begins grooming some eggs 
into a new generation of queens, while also laying unfertilized eggs that will mature into reproductive males 
called drones. This new crop of queens and males 
requires more food. But with summer over, 
the usual sources run dry, and the foraging wasps 
start taking more aggressive risks. By September, 
the hive’s organization deteriorates. Hungry workers no longer clean the nest 
and various scavengers move in. Just when it seems 
the hive can no longer sustain itself, the fertile queens and their drones 
depart in a massive swarm. As the days grow colder, 
the workers starve, and our queen 
reaches the end of her lifespan. But above, a swarm of reproductive wasps 
has successfully mated. The males die off shortly after, but the newly fertilized queens are ready 
to find shelter for their long sleep. And this woodpile looks like 
the perfect place to spend the winter.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In one summer, how large does a typical wasp nest grow to?
Options: A. Ping pong ball, B. Tennis ball, C. Softball, D. Basketball
Correct Option: D

As the April sun rises 
on a pile of firewood, something royal stirs inside. This wasp queen is one of thousands 
who mated in late autumn and hibernated through the winter. Now she emerges into the spring air 
to begin her reign. Most of her sisters weren’t so lucky. While hibernating in compost piles

led other queens to emerge early, only to find there was no available food. And some queens that survived the winter 
fell victim to the threats of spring, such as carnivorous plants, birds, 
and manmade pesticides. Our queen is the lone survivor 
of her old hive, and now, she must become 
the foundress of a new one. But first, breakfast. The queen heads for a citrus grove 
full of honeybee hives. The bees can be dangerous if provoked, but right now they’re paralyzed 
by the morning cold. Their hairy bodies are dripping

for a safe nesting area. This tree hollow, safe from rain, wind, 
and predators, is ideal. She chews the surrounding wood

into each cell, producing as many as 12 in 20 minutes. Within a week,

substance that sustains their mother. By the end of July, these first larva 
have matured into adult workers, ready to take on foraging,

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do most wasp queens not survive hibernation?
Options: A. They emerge early due to warm winters, B. They are eaten by spiders, C. They cannot find enough food, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Wasps are generally non-aggressive and avoid confrontations., D. Wasps rely on their speed to evade predators and avoid stinging. Correct Option: B
Question 5: How do wasp larvae contribute to the sustenance of their mother, the queen? Options: A. By producing a sugary substance from digested insects to feed the queen., B. By laying eggs to increase the hive population and provide more workers., C. By foraging for food outside the hive and bringing back nutrients., D. By defending the hive against predators and protecting the queen. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the typical lifespan of a worker wasp? Options: A. Several months, allowing them to contribute to the hive's growth., B. Roughly 3 weeks, requiring the queen to constantly lay new eggs., C. A few days, making them a short-lived but essential part of the hive., D. A year or more, allowing them to become a dominant force in the ecosystem. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Analyze the role of wasps in the ecosystem. What would likely happen if wasp populations declined significantly? Options: A. Spider and mite populations would decrease, causing a ripple effect in the ecosystem., B. Crop-eating insect populations would decrease, benefiting farmers and gardeners., C. Spider and mite populations would increase, potentially harming crops and gardens., D. Pollination of fruits and vegetables would increase, benefiting plant diversity. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How do wasps contribute to the process of winemaking? Options: A. By pollinating grapevines and increasing fruit production., B. By controlling pests that damage grapes and reducing disease., C. By biting into grapes and jump-starting fermentation to produce wine., D. By providing a source of yeast for fermentation and influencing flavor. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Synthesize the information about the wasp queen's life cycle. What is the primary goal of the queen's activities in the summer? Options: A. To establish a new hive, lay eggs, and expand the colony., B. To forage for food, defend the hive, and maintain the status quo., C. To groom a new generation of queens and prepare for succession., D. To prepare the hive for winter, reduce activity, and conserve energy. Correct Option: A
Question 10: Evaluate the impact of human actions on wasp populations. What is a potential consequence of using pesticides to control wasp populations? Options: A. The wasp population will decline, but other wildlife will be unaffected and thrive., B. The wasp population will decline, and other wildlife will benefit from reduced competition., C. The wasp population will decline, and other wildlife will also be harmed due to the broad impact of pesticides., D. The wasp population will increase, and other wildlife will be unaffected by the pesticides. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the options in Question 1 do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, the question content and intent are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks why most wasp queens do not survive hibernation, and the correct option is "all of the above," which includes emerging early due to warm winters, being eaten by spiders, and not finding enough food.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the April sun rises 
on a pile of firewood, something royal stirs inside. This wasp queen is one of thousands 
who mated in late autumn and hibernated through the winter. Now she emerges into the spring air 
to begin her reign. Most of her sisters weren’t so lucky. While hibernating in compost piles 
and underground burrows, many sleeping queens 
were eaten by spiders. Warm winters caused by climate change 
led other queens to emerge early, only to find there was no available food. And some queens that survived the winter 
fell victim to the threats of spring, such as carnivorous plants, birds, 
and manmade pesticides. Our queen is the lone survivor 
of her old hive, and now, she must become 
the foundress of a new one. But first, breakfast. The queen heads for a citrus grove 
full of honeybee hives. The bees can be dangerous if provoked, but right now they’re paralyzed 
by the morning cold. Their hairy bodies are dripping 
with sugar water from an earlier feeding, and the resourceful queen 
licks them for a morning snack. Newly energized, our queen searches 
for a safe nesting area. This tree hollow, safe from rain, wind, 
and predators, is ideal. She chews the surrounding wood 
and plant fibers to make a paper-like pulp. Then she builds around 50 brood cells 
that comprise the beginning of her nest. Using sperm stored from last fall, the queen lays a fertilized egg 
into each cell, producing as many as 12 in 20 minutes. Within a week, 
these will hatch into female larva. But until then, the queen must hunt down 
smaller insects to feed her brood, all while expanding the hive, laying eggs,
and defending against intruders. Fortunately, our queen is well prepared. Unlike bees, wasps can sting as many times
as they need to. With such a busy schedule, 
the queen barely has time to feed herself. Luckily, she doesn’t have to. When she feeds an insect to her grubs, they digest the bug into a sugary 
substance that sustains their mother. By the end of July, these first larva 
have matured into adult workers, ready to take on foraging, 
building, and defense. The queen can now lay eggs full-time, sustaining herself on her worker’s spoils 
and their unfertilized eggs. Although each worker only lives 
for roughly 3 weeks, the queen’s continuous egg-laying 
swells their ranks. In just one summer, 
the nest reaches the size of a basketball, supporting thousands of workers. Such a large population needs to eat, and the nearby garden 
provides a veritable buffet. As the swarm descends, 
alarmed humans try to swat them. They even fight back with pesticides 
that purposefully poison wasps, and inadvertently impact 
a wide-range of local wildlife. But the wasps are actually vital 
to this ecosystem. Sitting at the top 
of the local invertebrate food chain, these insects keep spiders, mites, 
and centipedes, in check. Wasps consume crop-eating insects, making them particularly helpful 
for farms and gardens. They even pollinate fruits and vegetables, and help winemakers 
by biting into their grapes and jump-starting fermentation. This feast continues until autumn, 
when the foundress changes course. She begins grooming some eggs 
into a new generation of queens, while also laying unfertilized eggs that will mature into reproductive males 
called drones. This new crop of queens and males 
requires more food. But with summer over, 
the usual sources run dry, and the foraging wasps 
start taking more aggressive risks. By September, 
the hive’s organization deteriorates. Hungry workers no longer clean the nest 
and various scavengers move in. Just when it seems 
the hive can no longer sustain itself, the fertile queens and their drones 
depart in a massive swarm. As the days grow colder, 
the workers starve, and our queen 
reaches the end of her lifespan. But above, a swarm of reproductive wasps 
has successfully mated. The males die off shortly after, but the newly fertilized queens are ready 
to find shelter for their long sleep. And this woodpile looks like 
the perfect place to spend the winter.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are reproductive male wasps called?
Options: A. Drones, B. Foundress, C. Workers, D. Men
Correct Option: A

They die from lack of food and harsh winter conditions. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At any given moment, trillions of cells 
are traveling through your blood vessels, sometimes circling the body 
in just one minute. Each of these cells 
has its origins deep in your bones. Bones might seem rock-solid, 
but they’re actually quite porous inside. Large and small blood vessels 
enter through these holes. And inside most of the large bones 
of your skeleton is a hollow core filled with soft bone marrow. Marrow contains fat 
and other supportive tissue, but its most essential elements 
are blood stem cells. These stem cells are constantly dividing. They can differentiate 
into red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, and send about hundreds of billions 
of new blood cells into circulation every day. These new cells enter the bloodstream through holes 
in small capillaries in the marrow. Through the capillaries, they reach larger blood vessels 
and exit the bone. If there’s a problem with your blood, there’s a good chance 
it can be traced back to the bone marrow. Blood cancers often begin 
with genetic mutations in the stem cells. The stem cells themselves 
are not cancerous, but these mutations can interfere 
with the process of differentiation and result in malignant blood cells. So for patients with advanced 
blood cancers like leukemia and lymphoma, the best chance for a cure is often 
an allogeneic bone marrow transplant, which replaces the patient’s bone marrow 
with a donor’s. Here’s how it works. First, blood stem cells 
are extracted from the donor. Most commonly, blood stem cells are filtered out 
of the donor’s bloodstream by circulating the blood 
through a machine that separates it 
into different components. In other cases, 
the marrow is extracted directly from a bone in the hip, the iliac crest, 
with a needle. Meanwhile, the recipient 
prepares for the transplant. High doses of chemotherapy or radiation 
kill the patient’s existing marrow, destroying both malignant cells 
and blood stem cells. This also weakens the immune system, making it less likely 
to attack the transplanted cells. Then the donor cells are infused into 
the patient’s body through a central line. They initially circulate 
in the recipient’s peripheral bloodstream, but molecules on the stem cells, 
called chemokines, act as homing devices and quickly traffic them 
back to the marrow. Over the course of a few weeks, they begin to multiply and start producing
new, healthy blood cells. Just a small population 
of blood stem cells can regenerate a whole body’s 
worth of healthy marrow. A bone marrow transplant 
can also lead to something called graft-versus-tumor activity, when new immune cells 
generated by the donated marrow can wipe out cancer cells the recipient’s 
original immune system couldn’t. This phenomenon can help eradicate 
stubborn blood cancers. But bone marrow transplants 
also come with risks, including graft-versus-host disease. It happens when the immune system 
generated by the donor cells attacks the patient’s organs. This life-threatening condition 
occurs in about 30–50% of patients who receive donor cells 
from anyone other than an identical twin, particularly when the stem cells 
are collected from the blood 
as opposed to the bone marrow. Patients may take 
immunosuppressant medications or certain immune cells may be removed 
from the donated sample in order to reduce the risk 
of graft-versus-host disease. But even if a patient 
avoids graft-versus-host disease, their immune system 
may reject the donor cells. So it’s crucial to find the best match 
possible in the first place. Key regions of the genetic code 
determine how the immune system identifies foreign cells. If these regions are similar 
in the donor and the recipient, the recipient’s immune system 
is more likely to accept the donor cells. Because these genes are inherited, 
the best matches are often siblings. But many patients 
who need a bone marrow transplant don’t have a matched family member. Those patients 
turn to donor registries of volunteers willing to offer their bone marrow. All it takes to be on the registry is 
a cheek swab to test for a genetic match. And in many cases, 
the donation itself isn’t much more complicated 
than giving blood. It’s a way to save someone’s life with a resource 
that’s completely renewable.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the potential sources of bone marrow donation?
Options: A. Peripheral blood, B. Bone marrow, C. Cord blood, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where do the trillions of cells traveling through your blood vessels originate from? Options: A. The heart, B. The lungs, C. Deep in your bones, D. The liver Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the primary function of blood stem cells in the bone marrow? Options: A. To produce hormones, B. To filter waste, C. To differentiate into red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: C
Question 3: A patient with advanced leukemia is considering an allogeneic bone marrow transplant. What is the main goal of this procedure? Options: A. To boost the patient's immune system, B. To replace the patient's bone marrow with a donor's, C. To remove cancerous cells from the bloodstream, D. To increase the production of red blood cells Correct Option: B
Question 4: How do molecules on the stem cells, called chemokines, facilitate the bone marrow transplant process? Options: A. They destroy malignant cells, B. They weaken the immune system, C. They act as homing devices and traffic the stem cells back to the marrow, D. They produce new blood cells Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is graft-versus-tumor activity, and how does it benefit the recipient of a bone marrow transplant? Options: A. It is a life-threatening condition that attacks the patient's organs, B. It is a phenomenon where new immune cells generated by the donated marrow wipe out cancer cells, C. It is a type of chemotherapy that kills malignant cells, D. It is a medication that suppresses the immune system Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main risk associated with bone marrow transplants, and how often does it occur? Options: A. Graft-versus-host disease, occurring in 10-20% of patients, B. Graft-versus-host disease, occurring in 30-50% of patients, C. Rejection of the donor cells, occurring in 50-60% of patients, D. Infection, occurring in 20-30% of patients Correct Option: B
Question 7: How can the risk of graft-versus-host disease be reduced in patients undergoing a bone marrow transplant? Options: A. By taking immunosuppressant medications, B. By removing certain immune cells from the donated sample, C. By using a different type of chemotherapy, D. Both A and B Correct Option: D
Question 8: Why is it crucial to find the best match possible for a bone marrow transplant? Options: A. To reduce the risk of infection, B. To increase the production of red blood cells, C. To minimize the risk of graft-versus-host disease and rejection of the donor cells, D. To boost the patient's immune system Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the most common method of collecting blood stem cells from a donor, and what is the alternative method? Options: A. The most common method is extracting the marrow directly from a bone in the hip, and the alternative method is filtering the stem cells from the donor's bloodstream, B. The most common method is filtering the stem cells from the donor's bloodstream, and the alternative method is extracting the marrow directly from a bone in the hip, C. The most common method is taking a cheek swab, and the alternative method is giving blood, D. The most common method is giving blood, and the alternative method is taking a cheek swab Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the primary advantage of being on a donor registry for bone marrow transplants, and what is the process of joining the registry? Options: A. The primary advantage is that it is a way to save someone's life with a resource that is completely renewable, and the process involves a cheek swab to test for a genetic match, B. The primary advantage is that it is a way to boost one's immune system, and the process involves giving blood, C. The primary advantage is that it is a way to reduce the risk of graft-versus-host disease, and the process involves taking immunosuppressant medications, D. The primary advantage is that it is a way to increase the production of red blood cells, and the process involves removing certain immune cells from the donated sample Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

This question asks about the methods of collecting blood stem cells from a donor, which is related to the sources of bone marrow donation. Although it does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest one in terms of content and intent.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the potential sources of bone marrow donation. If I had to choose, I would say that Question 9 is the closest, but it would be better to generate a new MCQ that exactly matches the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
At any given moment, trillions of cells 
are traveling through your blood vessels, sometimes circling the body 
in just one minute. Each of these cells 
has its origins deep in your bones. Bones might seem rock-solid, 
but they’re actually quite porous inside. Large and small blood vessels 
enter through these holes. And inside most of the large bones 
of your skeleton is a hollow core filled with soft bone marrow. Marrow contains fat 
and other supportive tissue, but its most essential elements 
are blood stem cells. These stem cells are constantly dividing. They can differentiate 
into red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, and send about hundreds of billions 
of new blood cells into circulation every day. These new cells enter the bloodstream through holes 
in small capillaries in the marrow. Through the capillaries, they reach larger blood vessels 
and exit the bone. If there’s a problem with your blood, there’s a good chance 
it can be traced back to the bone marrow. Blood cancers often begin 
with genetic mutations in the stem cells. The stem cells themselves 
are not cancerous, but these mutations can interfere 
with the process of differentiation and result in malignant blood cells. So for patients with advanced 
blood cancers like leukemia and lymphoma, the best chance for a cure is often 
an allogeneic bone marrow transplant, which replaces the patient’s bone marrow 
with a donor’s. Here’s how it works. First, blood stem cells 
are extracted from the donor. Most commonly, blood stem cells are filtered out 
of the donor’s bloodstream by circulating the blood 
through a machine that separates it 
into different components. In other cases, 
the marrow is extracted directly from a bone in the hip, the iliac crest, 
with a needle. Meanwhile, the recipient 
prepares for the transplant. High doses of chemotherapy or radiation 
kill the patient’s existing marrow, destroying both malignant cells 
and blood stem cells. This also weakens the immune system, making it less likely 
to attack the transplanted cells. Then the donor cells are infused into 
the patient’s body through a central line. They initially circulate 
in the recipient’s peripheral bloodstream, but molecules on the stem cells, 
called chemokines, act as homing devices and quickly traffic them 
back to the marrow. Over the course of a few weeks, they begin to multiply and start producing
new, healthy blood cells. Just a small population 
of blood stem cells can regenerate a whole body’s 
worth of healthy marrow. A bone marrow transplant 
can also lead to something called graft-versus-tumor activity, when new immune cells 
generated by the donated marrow can wipe out cancer cells the recipient’s 
original immune system couldn’t. This phenomenon can help eradicate 
stubborn blood cancers. But bone marrow transplants 
also come with risks, including graft-versus-host disease. It happens when the immune system 
generated by the donor cells attacks the patient’s organs. This life-threatening condition 
occurs in about 30–50% of patients who receive donor cells 
from anyone other than an identical twin, particularly when the stem cells 
are collected from the blood 
as opposed to the bone marrow. Patients may take 
immunosuppressant medications or certain immune cells may be removed 
from the donated sample in order to reduce the risk 
of graft-versus-host disease. But even if a patient 
avoids graft-versus-host disease, their immune system 
may reject the donor cells. So it’s crucial to find the best match 
possible in the first place. Key regions of the genetic code 
determine how the immune system identifies foreign cells. If these regions are similar 
in the donor and the recipient, the recipient’s immune system 
is more likely to accept the donor cells. Because these genes are inherited, 
the best matches are often siblings. But many patients 
who need a bone marrow transplant don’t have a matched family member. Those patients 
turn to donor registries of volunteers willing to offer their bone marrow. All it takes to be on the registry is 
a cheek swab to test for a genetic match. And in many cases, 
the donation itself isn’t much more complicated 
than giving blood. It’s a way to save someone’s life with a resource 
that’s completely renewable.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these diseases is not a blood cancer?
Options: A. Leukemia, B. Lymphoma, C. Colon cancer
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At any given moment, trillions of cells 
are traveling through your blood vessels, sometimes circling the body 
in just one minute. Each of these cells 
has its origins deep in your bones. Bones might seem rock-solid, 
but they’re actually quite porous inside. Large and small blood vessels 
enter through these holes. And inside most of the large bones 
of your skeleton is a hollow core filled with soft bone marrow. Marrow contains fat 
and other supportive tissue, but its most essential elements 
are blood stem cells. These stem cells are constantly dividing. They can differentiate 
into red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, and send about hundreds of billions 
of new blood cells into circulation every day. These new cells enter the bloodstream through holes 
in small capillaries in the marrow. Through the capillaries, they reach larger blood vessels 
and exit the bone. If there’s a problem with your blood, there’s a good chance 
it can be traced back to the bone marrow. Blood cancers often begin 
with genetic mutations in the stem cells. The stem cells themselves 
are not cancerous, but these mutations can interfere 
with the process of differentiation and result in malignant blood cells. So for patients with advanced 
blood cancers like leukemia and lymphoma, the best chance for a cure is often 
an allogeneic bone marrow transplant, which replaces the patient’s bone marrow 
with a donor’s. Here’s how it works. First, blood stem cells 
are extracted from the donor. Most commonly, blood stem cells are filtered out 
of the donor’s bloodstream by circulating the blood 
through a machine that separates it 
into different components. In other cases, 
the marrow is extracted directly from a bone in the hip, the iliac crest, 
with a needle. Meanwhile, the recipient 
prepares for the transplant. High doses of chemotherapy or radiation 
kill the patient’s existing marrow, destroying both malignant cells 
and blood stem cells. This also weakens the immune system, making it less likely 
to attack the transplanted cells. Then the donor cells are infused into 
the patient’s body through a central line. They initially circulate 
in the recipient’s peripheral bloodstream, but molecules on the stem cells, 
called chemokines, act as homing devices and quickly traffic them 
back to the marrow. Over the course of a few weeks, they begin to multiply and start producing
new, healthy blood cells. Just a small population 
of blood stem cells can regenerate a whole body’s 
worth of healthy marrow. A bone marrow transplant 
can also lead to something called graft-versus-tumor activity, when new immune cells 
generated by the donated marrow can wipe out cancer cells the recipient’s 
original immune system couldn’t. This phenomenon can help eradicate 
stubborn blood cancers. But bone marrow transplants 
also come with risks, including graft-versus-host disease. It happens when the immune system 
generated by the donor cells attacks the patient’s organs. This life-threatening condition 
occurs in about 30–50% of patients who receive donor cells 
from anyone other than an identical twin, particularly when the stem cells 
are collected from the blood 
as opposed to the bone marrow. Patients may take 
immunosuppressant medications or certain immune cells may be removed 
from the donated sample in order to reduce the risk 
of graft-versus-host disease. But even if a patient 
avoids graft-versus-host disease, their immune system 
may reject the donor cells. So it’s crucial to find the best match 
possible in the first place. Key regions of the genetic code 
determine how the immune system identifies foreign cells. If these regions are similar 
in the donor and the recipient, the recipient’s immune system 
is more likely to accept the donor cells. Because these genes are inherited, 
the best matches are often siblings. But many patients 
who need a bone marrow transplant don’t have a matched family member. Those patients 
turn to donor registries of volunteers willing to offer their bone marrow. All it takes to be on the registry is 
a cheek swab to test for a genetic match. And in many cases, 
the donation itself isn’t much more complicated 
than giving blood. It’s a way to save someone’s life with a resource 
that’s completely renewable.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which one of these cells is not produced in the bone marrow?
Options: A. Red blood cells, B. White blood cells, C. Platelets, D. Cardiac cells
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where do the trillions of cells traveling through your blood vessels originate from? Options: A. The heart, B. The lungs, C. Deep in your bones, D. The liver Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the primary function of blood stem cells in the bone marrow? Options: A. To produce hormones, B. To filter waste, C. To differentiate into red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: C
Question 3: A patient with advanced leukemia is considering an allogeneic bone marrow transplant. What is the main goal of this procedure? Options: A. To boost the patient's immune system, B. To replace the patient's bone marrow with a donor's, C. To remove cancerous cells from the bloodstream, D. To increase the production of red blood cells Correct Option: B
Question 4: How do molecules on the stem cells, called chemokines, facilitate the bone marrow transplant process? Options: A. They destroy malignant cells, B. They weaken the immune system, C. They act as homing devices and traffic the stem cells back to the marrow, D. They produce new blood cells Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is graft-versus-tumor activity, and how does it benefit the recipient of a bone marrow transplant? Options: A. It is a life-threatening condition that attacks the patient's organs, B. It is a phenomenon where new immune cells generated by the donated marrow wipe out cancer cells, C. It is a type of chemotherapy that kills malignant cells, D. It is a medication that suppresses the immune system Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main risk associated with bone marrow transplants, and how often does it occur? Options: A. Graft-versus-host disease, occurring in 10-20% of patients, B. Graft-versus-host disease, occurring in 30-50% of patients, C. Rejection of the donor cells, occurring in 50-60% of patients, D. Infection, occurring in 20-30% of patients Correct Option: B
Question 7: How can the risk of graft-versus-host disease be reduced in patients undergoing a bone marrow transplant? Options: A. By taking immunosuppressant medications, B. By removing certain immune cells from the donated sample, C. By using a different type of chemotherapy, D. Both A and B Correct Option: D
Question 8: Why is it crucial to find the best match possible for a bone marrow transplant? Options: A. To reduce the risk of infection, B. To increase the production of red blood cells, C. To minimize the risk of graft-versus-host disease and rejection of the donor cells, D. To boost the patient's immune system Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the most common method of collecting blood stem cells from a donor, and what is the alternative method? Options: A. The most common method is extracting the marrow directly from a bone in the hip, and the alternative method is filtering the stem cells from the donor's bloodstream, B. The most common method is filtering the stem cells from the donor's bloodstream, and the alternative method is extracting the marrow directly from a bone in the hip, C. The most common method is taking a cheek swab, and the alternative method is giving blood, D. The most common method is giving blood, and the alternative method is taking a cheek swab Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the primary advantage of being on a donor registry for bone marrow transplants, and what is the process of joining the registry? Options: A. The primary advantage is that it is a way to save someone's life with a resource that is completely renewable, and the process involves a cheek swab to test for a genetic match, B. The primary advantage is that it is a way to boost one's immune system, and the process involves giving blood, C. The primary advantage is that it is a way to reduce the risk of graft-versus-host disease, and the process involves taking immunosuppressant medications, D. The primary advantage is that it is a way to increase the production of red blood cells, and the process involves removing certain immune cells from the donated sample Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that asks about the types of cells produced in the bone marrow and includes an option that is not a type of blood cell. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match this description.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The Vikings came from the rugged, 
inhospitable north known today as Scandinavia. As the Roman Empire 
flourished further south, Scandinavians had small settlements, 
no central government, and no coinage. Yet by the 11th century, the Vikings 
had spread far from Scandinavia, gaining control of trade routes 
throughout Europe, conquering kingdoms as far as Africa, and even building outposts 
in North America. The secret to their success 
was their ships. The formidable Viking longship had its origins 
in the humble dugout canoe, or log boat. For millennia, the inhabitants of Scandinavia 
had used these canoes for transportation. Dense forests and tall mountains 
made overland travel difficult, but long coastlines 
and numerous rivers, lakes, and fjords provided a viable alternative. The first canoes were simply hollowed out 
logs rowed with paddles. Over time, they added planks 
to the log boat base using the clinker, 
or "lapstrake," technique, meaning the planks overlapped and were fastened to each other 
along their edges. As the Roman Empire expanded north, some Scandinavians 
served in their new neighbors’ armies— and brought home 
Roman maritime technology. The Mediterranean cultures 
at the heart of the Roman Empire had large warships 
that controlled the sea, and cargo ships that transported goods 
along the waterways. These ships were powered by sail and oars and relied on a strong skeleton 
of internal timbers fastened to the outer planks 
with copper, iron, and wood nails. At first, Scandinavians 
incorporated this new technology by replacing their loose paddles 
with anchored oars. This change 
hugely improved the crew’s efficiency, but also required stronger ships. So boat builders began to use iron nails 
for fasteners rather than sewing. They abandoned 
the log boat base for a keel plank, and the boats became higher 
and more seaworthy. But these early ships retained the concept
of the original log boat: their strength 
depended on the outer shell of wood, not internal frames and beams. They were built as shells— 
thin-walled but strong, and much lighter than the Roman ships. Competing chieftains quickly refined 
the new ships to be even more efficient. The lighter the boat, 
the more versatile it would be and the less investment of resources 
it would require— an essential advantage 
in a decentralized culture without large supplies of people. These ships still had no sails— 
sails were costly, and for now the rowed ships 
could meet their needs. That changed 
after the Western Roman Empire collapsed in the 5th century. Western Europe 
took a heavy economic blow, leveling the playing field a bit 
for the Scandinavians. As the region revived, new and vigorous trade routes 
extended into and through Scandinavia. The wealth that flowed along these routes helped create a new, more prosperous 
and powerful class of Scandinavians, whose members 
competed constantly with each other over trade routes and territory. By the 8th century, 
a sailing ship began to make sense: it could go further, faster, 
in search of newly available plunder. With the addition of sails, the already light and speedy ships 
became nearly unbeatable. The Viking ship was born. Viking longships could soon carry 
as many as 100 Vikings to battle. Fleets of them 
could land on open beaches, penetrate deep into river systems, 
and be moved over land if need be. When not at war, the vessels were used to transport goods 
and make trade journeys. There were smaller versions 
for fishing and local excursions, and larger adaptations 
for open sea voyages capable of carrying 
tens of tons of cargo. Thanks to their inventiveness 
in the face of difficult terrain and weak economies, 
the Vikings sailed west, settled the North Atlantic 
and explored the North American coast centuries before any other Europeans 
would set foot there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: They learned new shipbuilding technology from:
Options: A. The Greeks, B. The Romans, C. The Chinese, D. The Americans
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What region, characterized by rugged terrain and inhospitable climate, did the Vikings originate from? Options: A. The Mediterranean region, B. Western Europe, C. Scandinavia, D. North America Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the primary factor that contributed to the Vikings' success in spreading throughout Europe and beyond? Options: A. Their centralized government and coinage system, B. Their strategic alliances and military conquests, C. Their advanced maritime technology, specifically the Viking longship, D. Their extensive trade network and mercantile skills Correct Option: C
Question 3: What traditional Scandinavian watercraft design was the Viking longship based on, which had been used for transportation for millennia? Options: A. The Roman warship, B. The Mediterranean cargo ship, C. The humble dugout canoe, or log boat, D. The sailing ship Correct Option: C
Question 4: What shipbuilding technique did the Scandinavians use to add planks to the log boat base, which improved the strength and seaworthiness of their ships? Options: A. The clinker, or "lapstrake," technique, B. The mortise and tenon technique, C. The copper nailing technique, D. The sewing technique Correct Option: A
Question 5: What significant change did the Scandinavians make to their ships after incorporating Roman maritime technology, which improved the crew's efficiency? Options: A. They replaced their loose paddles with anchored oars, B. They abandoned the log boat base for a keel plank, C. They added a sternpost rudder for better steering, D. They used copper nails for fasteners Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the primary advantage of the Viking ships compared to the Roman ships, which made them more suitable for exploration and trade? Options: A. They were heavier and more durable, B. They were lighter and more versatile, C. They were faster and more maneuverable, D. They were more expensive and more complex Correct Option: B
Question 7: What event in the 5th century contributed to the Scandinavians' ability to compete with other European powers and expand their trade routes? Options: A. The rise of the Roman Empire, B. The collapse of the Western Roman Empire, C. The Viking conquest of North America, D. The establishment of trade routes in Scandinavia Correct Option: B
Question 8: Why did the Scandinavians add sails to their ships, which enabled them to explore and plunder more extensively? Options: A. To increase their cargo capacity, B. To improve their maneuverability, C. To go further and faster in search of newly available plunder, D. To reduce their reliance on rowing Correct Option: C
Question 9: Approximately how many Vikings could a Viking longship carry to battle, making them a formidable force in European warfare? Options: A. 20-30, B. 50-60, C. 100, D. 200-300 Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the ultimate result of the Vikings' inventiveness in shipbuilding and exploration, which had a lasting impact on European history? Options: A. They established a centralized government in Scandinavia, B. They conquered the Mediterranean region, C. They settled the North Atlantic and explored the North American coast centuries before other Europeans, D. They developed a complex system of trade routes in Europe Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Transcript**:
The Vikings came from the rugged, 
inhospitable north known today as Scandinavia. As the Roman Empire 
flourished further south, Scandinavians had small settlements, 
no central government, and no coinage. Yet by the 11th century, the Vikings 
had spread far from Scandinavia, gaining control of trade routes 
throughout Europe, conquering kingdoms as far as Africa, and even building outposts 
in North America. The secret to their success 
was their ships. The formidable Viking longship had its origins 
in the humble dugout canoe, or log boat. For millennia, the inhabitants of Scandinavia 
had used these canoes for transportation. Dense forests and tall mountains 
made overland travel difficult, but long coastlines 
and numerous rivers, lakes, and fjords provided a viable alternative. The first canoes were simply hollowed out 
logs rowed with paddles. Over time, they added planks 
to the log boat base using the clinker, 
or "lapstrake," technique, meaning the planks overlapped and were fastened to each other 
along their edges. As the Roman Empire expanded north, some Scandinavians 
served in their new neighbors’ armies— and brought home 
Roman maritime technology. The Mediterranean cultures 
at the heart of the Roman Empire had large warships 
that controlled the sea, and cargo ships that transported goods 
along the waterways. These ships were powered by sail and oars and relied on a strong skeleton 
of internal timbers fastened to the outer planks 
with copper, iron, and wood nails. At first, Scandinavians 
incorporated this new technology by replacing their loose paddles 
with anchored oars. This change 
hugely improved the crew’s efficiency, but also required stronger ships. So boat builders began to use iron nails 
for fasteners rather than sewing. They abandoned 
the log boat base for a keel plank, and the boats became higher 
and more seaworthy. But these early ships retained the concept
of the original log boat: their strength 
depended on the outer shell of wood, not internal frames and beams. They were built as shells— 
thin-walled but strong, and much lighter than the Roman ships. Competing chieftains quickly refined 
the new ships to be even more efficient. The lighter the boat, 
the more versatile it would be and the less investment of resources 
it would require— an essential advantage 
in a decentralized culture without large supplies of people. These ships still had no sails— 
sails were costly, and for now the rowed ships 
could meet their needs. That changed 
after the Western Roman Empire collapsed in the 5th century. Western Europe 
took a heavy economic blow, leveling the playing field a bit 
for the Scandinavians. As the region revived, new and vigorous trade routes 
extended into and through Scandinavia. The wealth that flowed along these routes helped create a new, more prosperous 
and powerful class of Scandinavians, whose members 
competed constantly with each other over trade routes and territory. By the 8th century, 
a sailing ship began to make sense: it could go further, faster, 
in search of newly available plunder. With the addition of sails, the already light and speedy ships 
became nearly unbeatable. The Viking ship was born. Viking longships could soon carry 
as many as 100 Vikings to battle. Fleets of them 
could land on open beaches, penetrate deep into river systems, 
and be moved over land if need be. When not at war, the vessels were used to transport goods 
and make trade journeys. There were smaller versions 
for fishing and local excursions, and larger adaptations 
for open sea voyages capable of carrying 
tens of tons of cargo. Thanks to their inventiveness 
in the face of difficult terrain and weak economies, 
the Vikings sailed west, settled the North Atlantic 
and explored the North American coast centuries before any other Europeans 
would set foot there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Vikings came from:
Options: A. Greenland, B. Africa, C. Scandinavia, D. France
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:
